texts.shortText:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This small, slender klipfish has a flattened head and eyes set well-forward and high on top of the head. Dorsal fin low, with 33–37 spines and 7–11 rays, anterior spines not raised into a crest. Pelvic fin unusual in that it has 3 not 2 uncurled rays that are joined by a membrane along most of their length (giving ‘web-footed’ appearance and hence common name ‘platana’ klipfish). Colour pattern distinctive and off-white with about 8 transverse pink to purple bars, each with a darker outline, sides of body with bright white spots.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Lambert’s Bay to Algoa Bay.

Found on clean gravel substrata from the low intertidal to depths of at least 15 m, especially where the bottom is thrown into distinct ripples. Surprisingly-well camouflaged against pink coralline algae that cover many of the shells and pebbles. Usually found shallowly buried in the sediment with just the eyes showing above the sediment surface. If disturbed swims a short distance before diving back into the sand like an eel. Difficult to detect and probably much more common that existing observations suggest.
Details not studied, but a small-mouthed species that probably feeds mainly on amphipods, isopods, and other small invertebrates.

Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. This species has an unusually large, cylindrical penis. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.

Distinctive colour pattern and unusual gravel habitat makes this slender species fairly easy to identify. A second member of the genus, the Leprous platana klipfish X. leprosus occurs in the same habitat, but has more laterally placed eyes and is different in colour - being black with 3–5 broad white saddles across the back. The Deep-reef klipfish Pavoclinus smalei is similar in colour but has a much different shorter body and is not elongated.
